title: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome
diagnosis_topic: Compression of neurovascular structures at the thoracic outlet
setup_script: A 29-year-old competitive swimmer presents to your clinic with numbness and weakness in her right arm during training. Symptoms worsen with overhead activity and are sometimes associated with swelling and discoloration of the hand. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for vital signs
dynamic_flow.reply: BP 118/70 mmHg, HR 72 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8 °C.
Adson’s and Roos tests reproduce her symptoms. The radial pulse is absent when the head is turned to the right. There is mild thenar atrophy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests further neurologic exam
dynamic_flow.reply: Strength is reduced in intrinsic hand muscles, with sensory changes in the ulnar distribution.
Duplex ultrasound shows subclavian vein compression during provocative maneuvers. CTA demonstrates a cervical rib and venous congestion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders nerve conduction studies
dynamic_flow.reply: These reveal brachial plexus compression at the thoracic outlet.
Physical therapy focused on postural correction and first-rib mobilization is started. Symptoms improve initially.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays escalation of care
dynamic_flow.reply: Her symptoms progress, with worsening hand weakness and swelling.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about acute complications
dynamic_flow.reply: She develops arm swelling consistent with venous thrombosis (Paget-Schroetter syndrome).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident refers to vascular surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Vascular surgery discusses first rib resection and scalenectomy for persistent neurovascular compromise.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with surgical decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: Surgery is performed. Postoperatively, she begins physical therapy for range of motion and strengthening.
Compression may involve the brachial plexus, subclavian vein, or subclavian artery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Overhead athletes, cervical ribs, and repetitive trauma are common risk factors.
She undergoes physical therapy, avoids overhead exertion for 6 weeks, and gradually resumes training.

critical_decision_points: Use of provocative maneuvers and targeted imaging
Recognition of indications for surgical decompression
Management of acute thrombosis when present
Patient education on activity modification and postoperative care
